ï»¿Execution Version O Dated It M44 , 2015 COLLA3ORATION ARRANGEMENT relating to Global Infrastructure Facility Partnership Program
ï»¿Execution Version This Collaboration Arrangement is er tered into on , 2015 between: (1) MIZUHO BANK, LTD, headquartered at Otemachi Tower, 1-5-5, Otemachi, Chiyoda-ku, ki o 100-8176, Japan, ("Mizuho"; and (2) THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND E EVELOPMENT ("IBRD") and INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPI I T ASSOCIATION ("IDA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 20433, U the INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION, ("IFC") headquartered at 2121 Pennsylva ii1 Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20433, USA, and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY, ("IIGA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, D'' 20433, USA (the "World Baiik Group") (each a "Party" and together the "Parties"). Preamble (A) There is broad international recognition, as confirmed by the G20, the OECD, Inteil n: nal Organizations (1Os), the G71, and the private sector represented by the B20 that investir c i; the infrastructure of Emerging Markets and Developing Economies (EMDEs) is needed, to E x1 and access to basic services and raise living standards for all, and to meet global economit ;Ii wth targets. (B) Meeting this need presents a significant financing challenge. Given constraints on existing 3:i. ces of infrastructure finance-paticularly in the public sector-a redoubled and coordinated Eil: rt is needed to mobilize private sector finance for EMDE infrastructure. (C) There is an absence of robuist pipelines of structurally sound and bankable projects an : t s is understood to be the greatest barrier to achieving significantly more infrastructure investrr: r (D) Governments, development inance institutions, donors, and private investors share an in:E n" St in developing the market for pri,fate infrastructure finance in EMDEs: both on the demand sic i i the numbers of structurally soun J and bankable projects seeking finance, and gradual emer( E n e of EMDE infrastructure as a rE cognized asset class; and the supply side, in the range o :r /ate investors that actively particir ate in financing those projects. Achieving these goals will ben it rom collective action between this range of entities-to leverage resources and knowledgE :c find solutions to complex infrastructure financing challenges that no single institution could a:: eve alone. (E) In support of these goals, thE Parties propose the establishment of a Global InfrastructurE :I :ility Partnership Program ("GIF") The GIF will be an open global platform aiming at levera :i the efforts of the wide range of i istitutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastruci J E Nith the participation of private infrastructure investors, coalescing around project prel &i ion, structuring, and risk mitigatio i for individual infrastructure investments. In this regard, the (,I: lims to complement existing and proposed services and initiatives currently supported by thE ties and other prospective GIF partners. The GIF intends to provide resources to prepe lell- structured, infrastructure prcjects, and to serve as an additional mechanism for acces,ii: the expertise of the Parties and other GIF partners, in combination with guidance from pro 'lIE tive private sector financiers into project structures. The GIF thereby aims to achieve greater Io ' age of official resources in the face of substantial EMDE infrastructure needs-in particular :) I irge and complex projects with th- potential to attract significant private capital. (F) The Parties are now interested in collaborating in developing the Global Infrastructure 1 :ility Partnership Program, together with other partners. 2
ï»¿Execution Version Accordingly, the Parties have come to the following understanding: 1 Global Infrastructure Facility Partnership Program Framework 1.1 The GIF is intended :o be based on the preliminary objectives and principles set cIA Annex 1 (Preliminary GIF Fovndational Principles). The Parties acknowledge their mutual understanding that while the GIF Foundational Principles are an initial basis for their collaboration, they are of an ndicative nature and will continue to be developed amongst -: Parties and with other potential partners until the GIF is formally established. The final ver :, of these objectives and principl,s will be agreed upon by the GIF Partners and be reflected i I thI agreement establishing the GIF. 1.2 The Parties intend tc work together with any additional participants who may be collaborating on the GIF to ft rther enhance their coordination, in particular by developing i . 31F, with a view to formally establ shing the program by June 2015. 2 Further Collaboration 2.1 Pursuant to the forec oing, the Parties will use reasonable endeavors to continue 1:> collaborate in developing the GIF, including but not limited to: a. Nature and scope of collaboration under the GIF, such as proposed categories of partnership and the ioles, rights, and responsibilities associated with each catego b. Governance arrangements of the GIF; c. Operational policies 3pplicable to the GIF's operations; d. Scope of GIF activitiIs and sources/uses of GIF funds, including approach to proj :.t selection criteria and coordination with the Parties' existing facilities; and e. Any other aspects of collaboration required to finalize the design of the GIF, inclu in(I sharing best practice and experience with regard to project preparation, through tl E Ie of knowledge platforms for the infrastructure sector. 2.2 During the process of finaliz ng the design of the GIF, the multilateral development banks i ;i d in Annex 2 will be invited to participate as initial Technical Partners. Once the GIF design is f i 'ed, additional collaborative effoIs are required to develop the operational details for the G F: t all times complementing existing efforts and facilities and building upon the shared knowle 1(0 and experience of the Parties in :his area. This includes determining the level of coordination I E l: een the Parties and project origi iation process. 3 General 3.1 This Collaboration Arrangement is not a legally binding agreement or commitmen it y he Parties to enter into or provide support for any specific activity or project. The Parties acknowledge that the provisions of this Collaboration Arrangement represent their comma 1 understanding and intentions only and that the Parties do not intend to create or impose a v' gal obligations or liabilities on an/ Party. 3.2 This Collaboration Ai rangement is valid and effective for a period of one year frory 1 h: date thereof, unless superseded at an earlier date by the establishment of the GIF. 3.3 The Parties expect t: at this document and information with respect to the collabor i activities contemplated herein will be publicly disclosed. Such disclosure will be made in accordance with the Parties' *espective disclosure policies. The Parties plan to consult wit e: -,h 3
ï»¿Execution Version other concerning the manne and form of any acknowledgment of the other Party's suppo t regarding the activities. 3.4 Nothing in this arran 3ement will constitute or be construed as a waiver, renunciat : r other modification of any of tie privileges, immunities and exemptions granted to any of tt E Parties under their constituent documents, international conventions and any applicable lk vEs In witness whereof, each of the Par ties has caused this Collaboration Arrangement to be execut I two (2) counterparts of equal conteni and form by a duly authorized representative of each Party E 0 the date first set forth above. 4

ï»¿Execution Version THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTI(ill IND DEVELOPMENT, the INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION, the INTERNATIONA FINANCE CORPORATION and the MULTI ATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY By: Bertrand Badre Managing Director and WI Chief Financial Officer 6
ï»¿Execution Version Annex 1 Preli-ninary GIF Foundational Principles 1 Objectives 1.1 The objective of the GIF is to promote private sector investment in infrastructure Ir:) cts in emerging markets and de teloping economies (EMDEs) through robust project prepara or provision of appropriate risk mitigation instruments, and thereby increasing the commerci I 2 d institutional investor engage nent in the EMDE infrastructure market. It is focused on collaboration in complex put lic-private partnerships and projects with potential for commE 1:i viability which require projec: preparation resources, policy dialogue and eventual infrastr it -e financing solutions that no single institution could achieve alone. 1.2 To this end, the GIF aims to create a global platform to provide financial and coor Ji n tion resources in collaboration w th the project preparation, advisory, and financing efforts of t 1E ide range of donor and development finance institutions currently engaged in supporting EM[PF infrastructure, with the input and ideas of private infrastructure investors. GIF's engagem( rI :)uld stretch from upstream suppc rt on project definition, preparation, and investment feasibilit assessment, through to dowistream transaction preparation, financial structuring, and ris: mitigation/credit enhanceme it. 1.3 Over the longer tern, by contributing to the stock of high quality and well-structur :I infrastructure projects, the GIF can be expected to help in the development of EMDE infrastructure as an asset clE ss attractive to a wide range of private investors seeking Ion -:E m assets in faster growing eco iomies, but which until now have been presented only limitec infrastructure investment opportunities that meet their risk tolerance and investment profil 2 Operating Principles 2.1 The GIF intends to c perate according to the following core principles, to be finaliz ):l pon agreement among GIF partrers: (i) Leveraging the private sector-specializing in project financing modalities 1 -11 vill draw together comparative advantages of public and private sectors; (ii) Addressing pulic goods-focusing on core infrastructure; particularly thos: infrastructure projects that are climate friendly or trade enabling; (iii) Promoting susl ainability and inclusiveness-ensuring projects adhere to :) practice standarJs for social and environmental responsibility; and (iv) Collaborating, complementing and partnering for solutions-mobilizing t :h lical and financial resources of all partner entities-World Bank Group entities, mL It o eral development institutions, other public institutions, and private investors-in a innovative and f exible way, to complement existing capacities, achieve great n leverage and address the complex infrastructure financing challenges that ar! beyond the resources of any individual partner. 3 Institutional Arrangements and Governance 3.1 The GIF is expected to involve a wide range of stakeholders who are involved in h:? development and implementation of infrastructure projects, both public and private. GIF p I'Tr 3rs are expected to fall into one or more of the following categories: 7
ï»¿Execution Version (i) Funding Partners-Partners that provide financial contributions to the GIF v,i I a considered Fun ding Partners. (ii) Technical Partiers-Partners that can and who will agree to provide specifi:: technical advice and support to GIF activities including execution of GIF-func : :I activities and/or provision of GIF-backed credit enhancement or liquidity supf Crt instruments. (iii) Advisory Partners-Private investors or entities that represent the voice of commercial and'or institutional investment, whether pension funds, insurancE companies, sov ?reign wealth funds, banks or other financial institutions, as v 'll s other multilateral or bilateral agencies engaged in supporting private sector infrastructure pr )jects, to be invited into discussions related to project prepar it , optimal approacies to financial structuring, and the design and use of risk instruments, wit ) a view to ensure suitability of projects for commercial and/o institutional investment. 3.2 A GIF Governing Council is proposed to oversee the GIF's strategic programmii( management and use of fun is, and development of operational policies and procedures; a1i1: hold the GIF Management Lnit (see section 4.1) accountable for delivering on the facility':; objectives and principles, wi-h advice and support from the Advisory Partners. The comp( Et n of the Governing Council will b- agreed between IBRD and prospective partners, but is pror cs sto comprise representatives of Funding and Technical Partners. 3.3 An Advisory Counc il comprised of all GIF partners, chaired by the Managing Dii e: r and Chief Financial Officer cf the World Bank Group, will be periodically convened to facil t:tt coordination of GIF activities and support GIF operations. This Advisory Council will serve ;i 3 sounding board, providing guidance and support for GIF Management, and in particular m it-i view to ensuring suitability o projects for private sector investment. 4 Management 4.1 The GIF will be adm nistered by the World Bank Group, through a small, dedicatE 1 t, 3m established for this purpose the GIF Management Unit). The GIF Management Unit will fir c on as a coordinating body as pr)jects are identified for inclusion in the pipeline, and then mo '( toward technical support anc financing phases. The GIF Management Unit will not lead ir :v iual projects. 4.2 GIF activity implementation teams will be led by selected staff of Technical Partn( r institutions, coordinated by the GIF Management Unit in consultation with client governm( rtc according to specific project 'equirements and the project origination processes. CompoE it c of the implementation teams may vary according to the need of individual projects and governments. 5 Activities and Projects 5.1 Project selection cr iteria and processes could be developed to reflect the folio 1v n: principles: (i) Development Iripact-projects that support the development goals of the G F partner institutio is; (ii) Alignment-prciects that are aligned with recipient/sponsor country priorities E n, strategies; (iii) Complexity-pro)jects that require multiple parties to come together to provid a structuring, arranging and financial support, and/or projects which require a b e- of financial instruments; and 8
ï»¿Execution Version (iv) Catalytic Impact-projects that have significant potential to achieve financia viability, leverage public funds, and attract private sector and/or institutional investors-such as through Public-Private Partnership (PPP) modalities-wl In ill meeting govern nent's service delivery objectives. The GIF will focus on infrast*ucture investments that have global public good characterist .s such as climate friendly-projec:s that are low emitting or encourage efficiency in the provisic n c infrastructure services; and , rade enabling-projects that facilitate or enhance interconn,< tr ity and trade. 5.2 The scope of supp >rt provided to a particular project will be defined flexibly, wit 1: iew to complementing the resou ces and support already available from partner entities and (1:11, funding mechanisms. Durin( the GIF pilot phase, this support may include the following a:: ii ies, corresponding to major project development stages: (i) Project definition and enabling environment - sector planning and investment prioritization; project definition, including needs analysis and pre-feasibility sc (E ing; and legal, regukitory, or institutional reforms; (ii) Project preparat on and investment feasibility - feasibility studies, investment appraisal, and FPP structuring; (iii) Transaction sup:ort and financial structuring - preparing and implementing transactions, an J design of risk mitigation/credit enhancement packages; anc (iv) Financial arranging and credit enhancement - arranging and mobilizing finant iin packages from i range of sources and partners, 6 Operational Policies Sound operational policies- including in particular the management of environmental anc ial impacts and risks, and trans )arency in procurement-are critical to the success of infrast c ire projects in supporting sustai iable, inclusive development; as well as for investors in thost projects to manage financial reputational and legal risks. In developing the appropriate framework for GIF-supported operations, the GIF could draw upon existing arrangements f :' external implementing entitiEs under World Bank Partnership Programs. GIF partners will collaborate to establish an a )proach to fiduciary, environmental and social safeguards an:1 0 ier standards and policies, and Jevelop, manage and oversee an accreditation process for G IF Technical Partners who are expected to function as implementing entities for GIF activitie:; 9
